--- Mitchell Timin <zenguyuno@...> wrote:
> I read through that thread.  Now there are three
> ways
> of doing this! :)

Right...these are basically very similar approaches,
differing primarily in the amount of information input
into the net each step.
 
> Originally, I had only considered looking at the
> whole
> table, meaning that the ANN has inputs for the state
> of every position.

Yeah, in this case, the network is getting complete
information about the entire table every single step. 
Which, again, isn't a big deal with six cards, but it
won't scale to very large numbers of cards well.

> A second way of doing it, based on my
> misinterpretation of what you said, is to give to
> the
> ANN all of the CHANGES to the table.  Since the
> starting information is "all cards face down", the
> theoreticall, if you know all the changes, that's
> equivalent to knowing the exact state of the table.

Yeah, this is interesting.  Here you're inputting the
smallest amount of information necessary for the
network to play the game successfully.  I'm not sure
exactly how this would work in practice.

If, for example, the network outputs two positions,
and both are empty, there is no state change to the
table, right?  So you have no input to the network (I
suppose you could input all zeros).

So do you activate the network again, and take those
outputs?  Or do you just take the next highest outputs
that correspond to spaces occupied with cards? 

> Now I see what you have been talking about, which is
> to let the ANN have a small scanning window and let
> it
> spend several computational steps looking over the
> table.  At least, that's what Darren's method is
> when applied to this game.

Something like that, though as I said in my reply to
Ken, I don't really see much use in a "looking around"
phase (if all the cards were face up, that would be
different, but that would be a variation on the
rules).  But the basic idea is the same.  The network
basically has two viewports, each the size of one
card-space.  So it is only looking at two spots on the
tableau each turn, and either getting input for the
value of the card or input indicating there is no card
there, and then it outputs the next two spots to
check.

So no looking around before it makes its next
choices...but again, a similar idea.

> All of those may be worth trying.

Sure. :)
 
> There is another large architectural decision here,
> which I might get some opinions on.  I have been
> planning to start with a sharp threshold function
> for
> the activation function, rather than a sigmoidal
> function.  My reasoning is that, since the inputs
> and
> final outputs are binary, why not use binary
> neurons? 

Again, an interesting opportunity for experiment. :)

There's obviously no need for your input and output
layer to be anything but binary, but I'm not sure that
you want all your hidden units to be binary as well.

> The weight & thresholds will be the only floating
> point numbers in the ANN.  Everything else will be
> 0's
> and 1's, and integers to boot.  I think this will
> allow me to code a faster calculating ANN, which in
> turn speeds up the number of generations per hour.

I wouldn't think efficiency would be an overriding
concern, at least until you scale the domain up to
large numbers of cards.  I think the most interesting
aspect of experimenting in this domain is seeing how
the topology of the net evolves to handle memory, not
really the computational efficiency of the solutions.

And you shouldn't have a problem doing fairly large
runs in short periods of times, no matter which
activation function you use on your hidden nodes, as
long as the population size isn't huge and you keep
your domain fairly scaled down.

Derek
